original_text: In representing wetland-river interactions involving GIWs, many models assume that the wetland can discharge into a river but cannot receive overbank flows from it. In such models, the volume of water (or water level elevation) in a wetland and its corresponding threshold value (predominantly controlled by outlet elevation) are the prime determinants of wetland outflow (Feng et al., 2012; Hammer and Kadlec, 1986; Johnson et al., 2010; Kadlec and Wallace, 2009; Powell et al., 2008; Voldseth et al., 2007; Wen et al., 2013; Zhang and Mitsch, 2005). However, in regions characterised by widespread riparian wetlands that are hydraulically connected with adjacent rivers, wetland-river interaction is likely to be bidirectional. Such interactions should be quantified according to hydraulic principles involving relative river and wetland water level elevations as well as the properties of the connection between the two (Kouwen, 2013; Liu et al., 2008; Min et al., 2010; Nyarko, 2007; Restrepo et al., 1998). In the WATFLOOD model, for instance, riparian wetland-river interaction is modelled using the principle of Dupuit-Forchheimer lateral/radial groundwater flow (Kouwen, 2013). Since exchange between riparian wetlands and rivers can occur over the surface and/or through the subsurface, Restrepo et al. (1998) incorporated an equivalent transmissivity expression, obtained for wetland vegetation and the subsurface soil, into the Darcy flow equation of the MODFLOW model.
original_translation: Al representar las interacciones humedal-río que involucran GIWs, muchos modelos asumen que el humedal puede descargar en un río pero no puede recibir flujos de desbordamiento de este. En tales modelos, el volumen de agua (o la elevación del nivel del agua) en un humedal y su valor umbral correspondiente (controlado predominantemente por la elevación de salida) son los principales determinantes del flujo de salida del humedal (Feng et al., 2012; Hammer y Kadlec, 1986; Johnson et al., 2010; Kadlec y Wallace, 2009; Powell et al., 2008; Voldseth et al., 2007; Wen et al., 2013; Zhang y Mitsch, 2005). Sin embargo, en regiones caracterizadas por extensos humedales ribereños que están conectados hidráulicamente con ríos adyacentes, la interacción humedal-río es probablemente bidireccional. Estas interacciones deben cuantificarse de acuerdo con principios hidráulicos que involucran las elevaciones relativas del nivel del agua del río y del humedal, así como las propiedades de la conexión entre ambos (Kouwen, 2013; Liu et al., 2008; Min et al., 2010; Nyarko, 2007; Restrepo et al., 1998). En el modelo WATFLOOD, por ejemplo, la interacción humedal-río ribereño se modela utilizando el principio de flujo de agua subterránea lateral/radial de Dupuit-Forchheimer (Kouwen, 2013). Dado que el intercambio entre humedales ribereños y ríos puede ocurrir en la superficie y/o a través del subsuelo, Restrepo et al. (1998) incorporaron una expresión de transmisividad equivalente, obtenida para la vegetación del humedal y el suelo subsuperficial, en la ecuación de flujo de Darcy del modelo MODFLOW.

In such models, the volume of water (or water level elevation) in a wetland and its corresponding threshold value (predominantly controlled by outlet elevation) are the prime determinants of wetland outflow (Feng et al., 2012; Hammer and Kadlec, 1986; Johnson et al., 2010; Kadlec and Wallace, 2009; Powell et al., 2008; Voldseth et al., 2007; Wen et al., 2013; Zhang and Mitsch, 2005).
However, in regions characterised by widespread riparian wetlands that are hydraulically connected with adjacent rivers, wetland-river interaction is likely to be bidirectional.

Such interactions should be quantified according to hydraulic principles involving relative river and wetland water level elevations as well as the properties of the connection between the two (Kouwen, 2013; Liu et al., 2008; Min et al., 2010; Nyarko, 2007; Restrepo et al., 1998).
In the WATFLOOD model, for instance, riparian wetland-river interaction is modelled using the principle of Dupuit-Forchheimer lateral/radial groundwater flow (Kouwen, 2013).

Since exchange between riparian wetlands and rivers can occur over the surface and/or through the subsurface, Restrepo et al. (1998) incorporated an equivalent transmissivity expression, obtained for wetland vegetation and the subsurface soil, into the Darcy flow equation of the MODFLOW model.

properties of the connection between the.translated_key: propiedades de la conexión entre ambos
original_annotated_sentences: In representing wetland-river interactions involving GIWs, many models assume that the wetland can discharge into a river but cannot receive overbank flows from it.

In such models, the volume of water (or water level elevation) in a wetland and its corresponding threshold value (predominantly controlled by outlet elevation) are the prime determinants of wetland outflow (Feng et al., 2012; Hammer and Kadlec, 1986; Johnson et al., 2010; Kadlec and Wallace, 2009; Powell et al., 2008; Voldseth et al., 2007; Wen et al., 2013; Zhang and Mitsch, 2005).
However, in regions characterised by widespread riparian wetlands that are hydraulically connected with adjacent rivers, wetland-river interaction is likely to be bidirectional.

Such interactions should be quantified according to hydraulic principles involving relative river and wetland water level elevations as well as the
properties of the connection between the two
(Kouwen, 2013; Liu et al., 2008; Min et al., 2010; Nyarko, 2007; Restrepo et al., 1998).
In the WATFLOOD model, for instance, riparian wetland-river interaction is modelled using the principle of Dupuit-Forchheimer lateral/radial groundwater flow (Kouwen, 2013).

Since exchange between riparian wetlands and rivers can occur over the surface and/or through the subsurface, Restrepo et al. (1998) incorporated an equivalent transmissivity expression, obtained for wetland vegetation and the subsurface soil, into the Darcy flow equation of the MODFLOW model.
original_annotated_samples:
Such interactions should be quantified according to hydraulic principles involving relative river and wetland water level elevations as well as the
properties of the connection between the two
(Kouwen, 2013; Liu et al., 2008; Min et al., 2010; Nyarko, 2007; Restrepo et al., 1998).
translated_annotated_samples:
Estas interacciones deben cuantificarse de acuerdo con principios hidráulicos que involucran las elevaciones relativas del nivel del agua del río y del humedal, así como las
propiedades de la conexión entre ambos
(Kouwen, 2013; Liu et al., 2008; Min et al., 2010; Nyarko, 2007; Restrepo et al., 1998).
properties of the connection between the.translated_text:
Al representar las interacciones humedal-río que involucran GIWs, muchos modelos asumen que el humedal puede descargar en un río pero no puede recibir flujos de desbordamiento de este. En tales modelos, el volumen de agua (o la elevación del nivel del agua) en un humedal y su valor umbral correspondiente (controlado predominantemente por la elevación de salida) son los principales determinantes del flujo de salida del humedal (Feng et al., 2012; Hammer y Kadlec, 1986; Johnson et al., 2010; Kadlec y Wallace, 2009; Powell et al., 2008; Voldseth et al., 2007; Wen et al., 2013; Zhang y Mitsch, 2005). Sin embargo, en regiones caracterizadas por extensos humedales ribereños que están conectados hidráulicamente con ríos adyacentes, la interacción humedal-río es probablemente bidireccional. Estas interacciones deben cuantificarse de acuerdo con principios hidráulicos que involucran las elevaciones relativas del nivel del agua del río y del humedal, así como las
propiedades de la conexión entre ambos
(Kouwen, 2013; Liu et al., 2008; Min et al., 2010; Nyarko, 2007; Restrepo et al., 1998). En el modelo WATFLOOD, por ejemplo, la interacción humedal-río ribereño se modela utilizando el principio de flujo de agua subterránea lateral/radial de Dupuit-Forchheimer (Kouwen, 2013). Dado que el intercambio entre humedales ribereños y ríos puede ocurrir en la superficie y/o a través del subsuelo, Restrepo et al. (1998) incorporaron una expresión de transmisividad equivalente, obtenida para la vegetación del humedal y el suelo subsuperficial, en la ecuación de flujo de Darcy del modelo MODFLOW.

original_annotated_sentences:
In
representing wetland-river interactions involving GIWs
, many models assume that the wetland can discharge into a river but cannot receive overbank flows from it.

In such models, the volume of water (or water level elevation) in a wetland and its corresponding threshold value (predominantly controlled by outlet elevation) are the prime determinants of wetland outflow (Feng et al., 2012; Hammer and Kadlec, 1986; Johnson et al., 2010; Kadlec and Wallace, 2009; Powell et al., 2008; Voldseth et al., 2007; Wen et al., 2013; Zhang and Mitsch, 2005).
However, in regions characterised by widespread riparian wetlands that are hydraulically connected with adjacent rivers, wetland-river interaction is likely to be bidirectional.

Such interactions should be quantified according to hydraulic principles involving relative river and wetland water level elevations as well as the properties of the connection between the two (Kouwen, 2013; Liu et al., 2008; Min et al., 2010; Nyarko, 2007; Restrepo et al., 1998).
In the WATFLOOD model, for instance, riparian wetland-river interaction is modelled using the principle of Dupuit-Forchheimer lateral/radial groundwater flow (Kouwen, 2013).

Since exchange between riparian wetlands and rivers can occur over the surface and/or through the subsurface, Restrepo et al. (1998) incorporated an equivalent transmissivity expression, obtained for wetland vegetation and the subsurface soil, into the Darcy flow equation of the MODFLOW model.
